rawLines.text: Cube control is the kubernetes CLI it
has many uses from applying
configuration to debugging to just
getting general information about what's
running on a kubernetes cluster today
I'm going to be going over how and why
you would use it let's say 95% of the
time we can run Cube control with Cube
CTL or cube cuddle usually followed by a
verb in this case we're going to do get
and in this case also we're going to run
it with the smallest Deployable unit in
kubernetes a pod so we're just going to
do Cube control get pod and it's going
to show us information about the pods
running on our cluster when we run this
though we get nothing because there's no
resources in the default namespace and
this is where this command is looking so
we need to search for namespaces and we
can do that with Cube control get
namespaces many of these resources names
are pretty flexible they take singular
or plural naming for example we could do
Cube control git namespace or cube
control git NS let's actually make this
NS and this is going to print to the
screen the different namespaces that
this cluster has we're now going to use
this demo namespace on this screen and
look for individual pods within that
namespace we can do that with Cube
control get pods like we did before but
this time we're going to use dasn and
the name of that namespace in this case
demo this is going to print information
about the pods to the screen finally now
a note here is DN is a global command
line option it can be applied to all
other commands that we're going to see
today and you can see more of those in
Cube control options and if we didn't
want to specify namespace we can
actually just use- capital A but we're
going to be specifying on name space for
the rest of today okay when we run this
like I said said we get some information
about the pods on the screen we can
adjust the output of this command with
the- O command so I'm going to clear the
screen and we're going to run this one
more time we're going to do the- O
command and in this case we're going to
specify wide this wider output gives us
more information about each pod like the
node it's running on and its IP address
we can also run this with- o Json if we
wanted to do some let's say Json
manipulation that's going to give us a
lot more information to the screen we
can run this against JQ for example see
my other video now Cube control get pods
only retrieves information about how the
Pod is stored in the API server most of
the time if you want more pod
information and additional contextual
information about the Pod you can use
the describe command and also pass in an
individual pod name you can do that with
Cube control describe pod again our
namespace in this case demo and then the
name of the Pod I'm just going to go up
here right above and just copy one of
these and put it right down here this is
not only going to give us a more human
readable format from information about
the Pod also more information it's also
going to give us runtime information in
this case event or individual errors or
the status of health checks and
Readiness checks right a lot more
contextual information for example let's
say you had a failing pod you can run
Cube control get pods to see the
individual pods or see those failing
pods and then you run Cube control
describe and that pod name to get more
information like if it's doing a crash
loop back off or there's an image pool
error right it will show you information
in the events here on this screen that
won't show you necessarily when you run
the describe but let's say you want to
dive a bit deeper and suspect there
might be issue with an application
running with inside of a pod another
useful command is Cube control logs now
it's a little bit different format you
don't do get logs you just do logs and
then this case a pod name which we still
had in our buffer from earlier now you
still have to specify name space which
is going to be demo and this is going to
show you logs from the individual
container this is particularly helpful
for troubleshooting or understanding
what's happening with an inside of a pod
now confusingly you can get logs from a
pod by specifying the name but you can
also do so by specifying the type and
name of an individual resource that
isn't just a pod for example if I wanted
to get logs from a specific deployment I
can do that by specifying deployment
slash the name of the deployment in this
case just demo app right this is going
to show us logs from that whole
deployment now this is going to show
logs for a default container it's going
to pick a container if you have multiple
containers within a pod uh but if you
wanted you can specify an individual
container that you want to see logs for
with the- C command and that will
specify just one container to see logs
for you can also follow Logs with the- f
command and it's just going to keep
streaming the logs to your client okay
now that's the basics let's rapid fire
talk about the different ways you can
manipulate the data with sorting filters
and selectors so like we did earlier
let's just do a cube control get pods
and specify our namespace but let's say
we wanted to sort these individual pods
by their creation timestamp we can do
that with the sort by flag and we can
specify in this case a part of the spec
here with metadata. creation time and
now when it prints get pods to the
screen it's going to sort them by when
they were created in this case
descending order or ascending order
descend descending order we can sort by
things like a deployment how many
replicas it has or you know how many
restarts an individual pod has right you
can play into when you dive into
exploring the spec a bit more and the
different parts of information that you
get back when you get information about
individual pod now that was sorting the
information that's returned sometimes
you only want to select or only want to
show certain parts you can do that with
the selector and then you specify a
label in this case we're going to use
app as the label we're going to select
on and the name of one of our apps that
we have deployed in this namespace
called
demo-2 and now this is only going to
show us the one pod that's a part of
demo demo app- two for example we remove
the -2 it's going to only show us the
other three apps that are running that
are not demo app -2 I can't say that
maybe I should have picked a better name
now this D- selector is also the same
thing as just using the the- L flag so
for example Cube control pods - L app
equals demo app right this is specifying
the label that is app equals demo app
it's only going to show us the pods that
have that label on to the screen okay
now let's talk about applying
configuration kubernetes can use yaml
files to define the desired state of
your cluster you can create yaml files
specifying your resources such as a
deployment or services or ingresses and
then apply it using the apply command
for example I have this app.yaml file
that's actually how I created the
resources for this demo right we can
just see it has a service in here and a
deployment and some basic information in
here right um we can apply that
configuration with Cube control apply
and then- F for file and then the name
of that file that you just saw on screen
and this is going to apply those
resources to the kubernetes cluster this
command reads the AML file and creates
or updates the resources defined in it
now there's Al a cube control create
command that does a similar thing but
that's for creating resources but it's
only for creation because the command's
not item potent so it can't be used for
updates for example I ran Cube control
apply DF here uh it actually already
existed right we're applying this is
basically an update to these individual
resources create doesn't have that
ability to be honest most of the
examples in documentation and the way
that I've used Cube control in general I
usually just use apply because it works
for both creation and update and it's
item potent which is good so if we want
to make changes we can just change the
Manifest here and run apply DF again and
it'll make those changes but we can also
actually edit the live configuration
within the cluster with the cube control
edit command we can do so with
specifying Cube control edit deployment
and it's going to open up Vim in this
case let's say we wanted to change the
number of replicas we have I'm just
going to search rep
because um yeah right here so on this
line we have have replica set to three
that means we have three individual pods
running in this configuration I'm just
going to change this to four and save
this and now it's going to apply that
edited configuration to our cluster and
if we do Cube control get pods in our
namespace we'll see now we have four of
those individual pods running instead of
three now a trick here I wouldn't
actually change replicas by editing the
live uh manifest like that if you want a
quick way to actually just scale up the
deployment there's an individual
kubernetes command or CBE control
command called C control scale you
specify the type and name of the
individual deployment the name space and
pass in the flag for replicas in this
case three and this is going to change
us back down to three replicas and we
can check that this has gone back to
three replicas if we do Cube control git
pods the name of the namespace and then
the label selector for that deployment
we had and that's going to only show us
the three that should be here now lastly
if you need to delete resources you can
use the delete command followed by the
resource type just like we've done
everything else so you do Cube control
delete uh in this case let's you know
let's delete a pod Cube C TL delete and
then the Pod we have to specify pods
delete pods cool and that's deleted an
individual pod for us now we can see
that pod was deleted if we run again run
git pods uh we can see that the
deployments recreated a new pod for us
18 seconds ago instead of these other
two that are over 2 hours old okay
that's some ways to manipulate
individual resources within a cluster
let's talk about exacting into an
individual pod so you can do some deeper
troubleshooting or investigations we can
use the cube control exec command and
then we're going to specify again name
space and the name of individual pod
that we can get from get pods and then
we need to add these two dashes now
these two dashes to separate the
commands from the kubernetes cube
control execution and flags and
Arguments for that and the flags and
arguments that you're going to want to
pass into your individual pod to exec
now in this case we're not going to do
any individual Flags we're just going to
run the ls Command right or actually
let's do h i let's see the individual
user this exec is running now this is
going to execute on the individual pod
that's running within our cluster and
we're going to see we get root for
example if we want to see LS right if we
just want to run the ls command this is
going to print the individual
directories now you can do this to send
individual commands but you also might
want to exec in and execute what it's
called raw terminal mode uh I guess
that's from the docs i' I've never
called it that I just call it exacting
in but you can do this by adding to your
individual Cube control exec command - I
and or sorry yeah - i and- t sometimes
seen is just- it you're going to want to
remember that you use that all the time
now what this is going to do is standard
into an individual command in this case
if we just add bash here it's going to
send standard into bash and it's also
going to send standard out and Standard
air back to the individual client this
is going to allow us to exec into this
individual pod so we now a new prompt is
propped up on the screen and we're now
within that individual pod and we can do
different commands like see how much
space is on the individual file system
of the Pod there's some depth here might
do a followup in the future some pods
don't have bash you might have to just
do sh this is the very Basics but moving
on for a sake of time you want to kind
of just remember the exact command as
it's written right dash dash the name of
your command in this case bash and then
that's how you get a shell into the Pod
cool you can exit with just exit by the
way moving on to some grab bag items uh
nodes you can get them with get Cube
control get nodes and this is going to
print the individual nodes that I have
in this cluster in this case I only have
two it's important to note didn't have
to specify names space here cuz these
nodes aren't namespaced you can do
individual actions against these nodes
let's say we wanted to disable
individual node from getting pod
scheduled to it we can do that with Cube
control cordin and then a name of a node
this is going to disable an individual
pod or an individual node for scheduling
pods against it so we can see that and
the effects it's had with Cube control
get nodes and we'll see one of the pods
has scheduling disabled right we can
also drain an individual node with the
same as we just did with cordin but
instead of cordin we can say drain and
this is yelling at us because of things
that don't matter but if you wanted to
drain that's how you would do it you can
also uncorded an individual node by just
saying UNC there's other information you
can get about nodes uh I don't have the
metrics API running on this individual
cluster but if I did I could run Cube
control top and then the name of a node
or just for node and we'd get
information about the node but like I
said don't have the metric API so uh
that's not going to work for this
cluster that's notes lastly you can get
cluster information Cube control cluster
info this is just going to give a basic
basic cluster info to the screen uh as
you can see in the output here you can
get some more information with Cube
control cluster info dump congrats
that's basically 95% of how I use Cube
control with the one exception being
earlier I mentioned setting up a config
let's talk a bit about doing that by
default Cube control looks for a file

directory you can specify other Cube

environment variable or setting the--
Cube config flag you can see what this

this is going to show that more

using at the individual moment now as an

missions it's very common you can change

control config use context and the name
